author: Andiswa Maqutu
title: Prasa ‘failed to hedge’ on locomotives deal | Transport & Tourism
text:
Picture: SUPPLIED Related articles Prasa gets Transnet nod to test tall locomotives Prasa’s silence on engineer’s degrees beyond awkward Prasa to probe allegations that chief engineer is unqualified for position In this article Companies and organisations: Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa INADEQUATE foreign currency hedging in a contract for locomotives could have forced the Passenger Rail Agency of SA (Prasa) to pay almost R5bn instead of R3.5bn.
The lack of hedging also means that the state agency will only procure 70 instead of the 88 Spanish-made locomotives it originally sought.
Prasa is procuring 20 diesel and 50 hybrid locomotives from Spanish manufacturer Vossloh Espana, through a consortium, Swifambo Rail Leasing.
The hedging inadequacy is the latest question raised over the tender.
Reports say the first 13 diesel locomotives delivered to Prasa at a cost of R600m are the wrong height and will damage existing rail infrastructure.
At the closing date for the tender submissions in 2011, the contract was valued at R3.5bn based on a euro-rand exchange rate of R10.18 and locomotive price of €3,822,900 each.
However, due to delays, the rand had weakened by nearly R3 by the time the contract was signed in 2013, bringing the value of the contract to more than R5bn.
The number of locomotives was then revised down to 70, valued at about R4.8bn.
A memo seen by Business Day written by Prasa GM Siphiwe Mathobela to group CEO Lucky Montana last year, details the effect of the euro-rand exchange rate.
He described Prasa’s foreign exchange position in the contract as "a floor without a ceiling or roof".
The contract stipulates that Prasa and Swifambo would share the currency risk.
Swifambo submitted a price for the deal at an exchange rate of R10.18 with a clause in the contract saying it would be liable for currency risk up to the R10.40 mark.
Prasa would be responsible for the currency risk above this mark, Mr Mathobela said.
"It goes without saying that procuring the locos at more than R5bn is a costly option," said Mr Mathobela
Prasa should have stipulated that it would be responsible for the fluctuation of the rand against the euro up to R10.62, which would have pushed the contract up to R3.9bn, he said.
Prasa had not responded to requests for comment yesterday by the time of going to press.
Last week, Mr Montana said Prasa was monitoring the currency risk in the contract.
"We will review the numbers, because if it reaches a point where it is not sustainable we have to look at that," he said.
"And we will go to the government or Treasury and say, ‘look we have got a problem, we think we should be reviewing the contract’. But we are monitoring it very closely."
Mr Mathobela had recommended that the contract be reviewed and a fixed rate of R11 be agreed upon as Swifambo was "unlikely" to agree to R10.62 — because it was based on 2011 figures, but could still make a profit.
Swifambo’s "all-in price" of R10.40, which was "translated as the maximum currency loss" the consortium was willing to take, meant it had probably hedged its position, Mr Mathobela said.
"With the current situation we (Prasa) find ourselves in, they (Swifambo) have priced in a way that they will be getting more rands to buy fewer euros for their payments in Europe," Mr Mathobela said in the memo.
Prasa has also entered into a R51bn deal with Gibela Rail Consortium for 3,600 Alstom-built coaches.
Mr Montana said the hedging on this contract was dealt with by the Treasury because of its size.
